body: This seems a good idea and an oversight from our part. Would you like to send a PR?
@mcollina sure no problem. Will do it today or tomorrow ;)

body: I may have misunderstood this feature request, it might not land, or maybe make it into Fastify@3.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

Let us start discussing this again, otherwise, we will not be able to make it land in v3 if we decide to adopt it.


Related: https://github.com/fastify/fastify/issues/1049 https://github.com/fastify/fastify/pull/1051 https://github.com/fastify/fastify/pull/1595
I think we should do this.
I think we should do it as well.

Should this be treated as a documentation issue, or should the breaking change be made? It _appears_ like this is a contentious issue, as I find @jsumners comment is appropriate and yet the underlying argument to change the code to 302 is also fair.

@GlenTiki How I see it, if a developer comes from express to fastify this can be an issue that he would end up at. But we can either fix it by adding some clear documentation, or make a breaking change and do it the same as express is doing it. :)

So if I do:

```js
reply.status(303)
// proceed through the request chain to some ultimate handler that does
reply.redirect('/foo')
```

Your assertion is that the result should be?:

```
HTTP/1.1 302 Found
Location: /foo
```

When what I really said to do is:

```
HTTP/1.1 303 See Other
Location: /foo
```

@jsumners yes indeed. The code above can cause a situation where the developer doesn't know here the 303 status was set. So the solution I'm proposing makes this clearer since the developer is required to specify the status code. If not it's the default 302
